questions.question: Which of the following popular apps is built using Flutter?
options: Google Ads
Alibaba
BMW App
All of the above

questions.question: Which of the following is a benefit of using Flutter Inspector?
options: It allows you to visualize and debug the widget tree structure in real-time.
It helps in writing unit tests for Flutter applications.
It provides a built-in database for storing application data.
It automatically generates code for you based on UI design.

questions.question: Which of the following are popular editors for Flutter development?
options: Android Studio
Visual Studio Code
Xcode
Sublime Text

questions.question: How comfortable are you with naming the command used to compile the release mode in Flutter?

easy.question: What is the command to compile the release mode in Flutter?
options: flutter run --release
flutter build apk --release
flutter compile release
flutter run --profile

medium.question: Which of the following commands will generate a release build for an Android app in Flutter?
options: flutter run --release
flutter build apk --debug
flutter build apk --release
flutter build ios --release

hard.question: What is the correct sequence of commands to compile a release build for both Android and iOS in Flutter?
options: flutter build apk --release, flutter build ios --release
flutter run --release, flutter build apk --release
flutter build apk --debug, flutter build ios --debug
flutter compile release, flutter build all --release

questions.question: How comfortable are you with can you state a few examples of stateless widget?

easy.question: Which of the following is an example of a stateless widget in Flutter?
options: Text
StatefulWidget
AnimatedContainer
FutureBuilder

medium.question: What is a key characteristic of a stateless widget in Flutter?
options: It can change its appearance based on user interaction
It cannot change its appearance once created
It must have a build method
It can be used to manage complex state

hard.question: Which of the following statements about stateless widgets is true?
options: They can only be used for static content
They can be used to create interactive UI elements as long as the interaction does not change the widget's configuration
They are always more efficient than stateful widgets
They cannot be used with other widgets in a widget tree

questions.question: How many kinds of widgets are there in Flutter?
options: Two (Stateless and Stateful)
Three (Stateless, Stateful, and Inherited)
Four (Stateless, Stateful, Inherited, and Custom)
Five (Stateless, Stateful, Inherited, Custom, and Animated)

questions.question: How comfortable are you with can you tell us what will be the default return type, if you don't specify the return type for a function?

easy.question: What is the default return type in Dart if you don't specify one?
options: void
dynamic
int
String

medium.question: In Dart, what happens when a function doesn't specify a return type?
options: It returns null
It returns the last evaluated expression
It throws an error
It returns a default value

hard.question: Which of the following statements about Dart's default return type is true?
options: The default return type is always null
The default return type is dynamic, meaning it can be any type
The default return type is void, but only if the function doesn't return anything
The default return type is determined at runtime based on the function's usage

questions.question: How comfortable are you with can you tell us what you know about rune in dart??

easy.question: What is a Rune in Dart?
options: A special type of string
A Unicode code point
A type of variable
A function

medium.question: Which of the following is a valid way to represent a Rune in Dart?
options: String.fromCharCode(97)
Rune('a')
Unicode('a')
Char('a')

hard.question: How would you iterate over the runes of a string in Dart?
options: for (var r in string.runes) { ... }
for (var r in string.chars) { ... }
for (var r in string.unicode) { ... }
for (var r in string.iterate) { ... }

questions.question: Which function compiles and updates the app in Flutter?
options: build()
main()
runApp()
setState()

questions.question: How comfortable are you with using WidgetsApp for basic navigation?

easy.question: What is the primary purpose of WidgetsApp in Flutter?
options: To handle complex animations
To provide basic navigation between screens
To manage state in the application
To connect to backend services

medium.question: Which of the following is a common use case for WidgetsApp in Flutter?
options: Creating a custom widget from scratch
Navigating between different screens in an app
Styling text and buttons
Handling user authentication

hard.question: How does WidgetsApp typically facilitate navigation in a Flutter application?
options: By using the Navigator widget to push and pop routes
By directly manipulating the widget tree
By calling platform-specific APIs for navigation
By using a state management solution like Provider

questions.question: How comfortable are you with defining the spacer widget in Flutter?

easy.question: What is the primary purpose of the Spacer widget in Flutter?
options: To create fixed-size empty space between widgets
To add decorative elements to the UI
To handle user input events
To manage widget state

medium.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid way to use the Spacer widget?
options: Spacer()
Spacer(width: 20)
Spacer(height: 20)
Spacer(flex: 2)

hard.question: In a Row widget, how does the Spacer widget distribute space when multiple Spacer widgets are present with different flex factors?
options: It distributes space proportionally based on the flex factors
It gives equal space to all Spacer widgets regardless of flex factors
It ignores the flex factors and distributes space equally
It throws an error when multiple Spacer widgets are used

questions.question: What is the difference between runApp() and main() in Flutter?
options: runApp() is the entry point of the application, while main() is a method that initializes the app.
runApp() is a method that initializes the app, while main() is the entry point of the application.
runApp() is used to display the app on the screen, while main() is used to define the app's structure.
runApp() is a widget, while main() is a function that calls runApp().

questions.question: Which of the following is a type of stream in Dart?
options: Single subscription stream
Broadcast stream
Both Single subscription and Broadcast stream
Neither

questions.question: What is the difference between mainAxisAlignment and crossAxisAlignment in Flutter?
options: mainAxisAlignment controls alignment along the main axis of a widget, while crossAxisAlignment controls alignment along the cross axis
mainAxisAlignment and crossAxisAlignment are the same and can be used interchangeably
mainAxisAlignment controls the size of the widget, while crossAxisAlignment controls the color
mainAxisAlignment is used for vertical alignment and crossAxisAlignment is used for horizontal alignment

questions.question: How comfortable are you with differentiating between `StatelessWidget` and `StatefulWidget` in Flutter?

easy.question: Which widget in Flutter does not maintain any state and is immutable?
options: StatefulWidget
StatelessWidget
StatefulWidget and StatelessWidget
None of the above

medium.question: What is the primary difference between `StatelessWidget` and `StatefulWidget` in Flutter?
options: StatelessWidget can be modified after creation, while StatefulWidget cannot.
StatefulWidget can be modified after creation, while StatelessWidget cannot.
StatelessWidget and StatefulWidget are the same.
None of the above.

hard.question: When should you use a `StatefulWidget` instead of a `StatelessWidget` in Flutter?
options: When the widget's appearance changes in response to user interaction or other events.
When the widget's appearance never changes.
When the widget is part of a list.
When the widget is part of a form.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with differentiating between the final, const, and static keywords in Dart?

easy.question: Which keyword is used to declare a variable that can only be assigned once?
options: final
const
static
var

medium.question: What is the difference between a final and a const variable in Dart?
options: final variables can be assigned once, while const variables are compile-time constants
const variables can be assigned once, while final variables are compile-time constants
final and const variables are the same
final variables are immutable, while const variables are mutable

hard.question: In which scenario would you use the static keyword in Dart?
options: To declare a variable that belongs to the class rather than an instance of the class
To declare a variable that can only be assigned once
To declare a compile-time constant
To declare a variable that is immutable

questions.question: What is the key difference between named and positional parameters in Flutter?
options: Named parameters are passed with parameter names, while positional parameters are passed by their order in the function definition.
Named parameters are always required, while positional parameters are optional.
Named parameters are used for constructors, while positional parameters are used for regular functions.
Named parameters are always optional, while positional parameters are always required.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with explaining BuildContext in Flutter?

easy.question: What is the primary purpose of BuildContext in Flutter?
options: To provide a way to access the nearest ancestor widget in the widget tree
To store and manage application state
To handle user input events
To define the layout of a widget

medium.question: Which of the following methods can be used to find the nearest ancestor of a specific type using BuildContext?
options: findAncestorWidgetOfExactType()
findByType()
locateAncestor()
getAncestor()

hard.question: In a Flutter application, what happens if you try to use BuildContext from a widget that has been disposed?
options: It throws an exception because the widget tree is no longer valid
It returns null
It silently fails and returns an empty BuildContext
It creates a new BuildContext for the disposed widget

questions.question: How comfortable are you with explaining the Container class in Flutter?

easy.question: What is the primary purpose of the Container class in Flutter?
options: To create a scrollable widget
To provide a box model for layout and styling
To manage state in a widget tree
To handle animations and transitions

medium.question: Which of the following properties can you set on a Container widget in Flutter?
options: color, padding, margin, alignment
onTap, onLongPress, onHover
child, children, index
width, height, maxWidth, maxHeight

hard.question: How does the Container class differ from the Column and Row classes in Flutter?
options: Container is a layout widget, while Column and Row are alignment widgets
Container is a single-child widget, while Column and Row can have multiple children
Container is used for styling, while Column and Row are used for layout
Container is a stateful widget, while Column and Row are stateless

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Flutter Inspector?
options: To debug and inspect the widget tree and layout of a Flutter application
To manage state in a Flutter application
To handle animations in a Flutter application
To optimize the performance of a Flutter application

questions.question: What is the difference between packages and plugins in Flutter?
options: Packages are reusable code libraries, while plugins are packages that interact with native code
Plugins are reusable code libraries, while packages are plugins that interact with native code
Packages and plugins are the same thing in Flutter
Packages are used for UI components, while plugins are used for state management

questions.question: How comfortable are you with explaining profile mode in Flutter?

easy.question: What is the primary purpose of profile mode in Flutter?
options: To debug and profile the performance of an app
To run the app in a production environment
To test the app on different screen sizes
To simulate network conditions

medium.question: Which of the following tools is used to analyze performance in profile mode?
options: Flutter Inspector
Flutter DevTools
Android Profiler
Xcode Instruments

hard.question: How can you enable profile mode in a Flutter app?
options: By running `flutter run --profile` in the terminal
By selecting 'Profile' in the run configuration in Android Studio
By adding `profile: true` in the `pubspec.yaml` file
By enabling it in the device's developer settings
